instruction: How does the performance of the MLA ensembles in classifying Raman spectroscopy data compare to traditional methods in predicting oral cancer risk?
Output:
The performance of the MLA ensembles in classifying Raman spectroscopy (RS) data is superior to traditional methods in predicting oral cancer risk. The results of the past study showed that when the RS of oral epithelial cells from different study groups (normal-healthy volunteers, potentially cancerable leucoplakia, and cancer patients with oral squamous cell carcinoma) were classified using the MLA ensembles, the overall accuracy was 88% with a deviation of 8%. 

In comparison, when the Decision Tree Classifier (DTC) was applied individually, the overall accuracy was only 48% with a deviation of 19%. Similarly, when the Support Vector Machine (SVM) was applied individually, the overall accuracy was 58% with a deviation of 15%. 

Furthermore, the class-wise evaluation demonstrated that the LDA-SVM ensemble outperformed the LDA-DTC ensemble in terms of performance. 

To assess the classifier ensembles' performance in cancer risk prediction, a blind test was conducted using RS data from habitual cigarette smokers (CS) as the susceptible group and healthy volunteers as the control group. The LDA-SVM ensemble showed the highest classification accuracy, indicating its ability to accurately detect oral cancer risk and screen susceptible patients.
